body: Another note, `\count()` seems to be considered pure by psalm, but it is actually not ðŸ˜›

> Another note, \count() seems to be considered pure by psalm, but it is actually not ðŸ˜›

Please ticket that separately

issue.title: add `pure-callable` type and ban using callable arguments in pure context.

repository.name: psalm
repository.description: A PHP static analysis tool for finding errors and security vulnerabilities in PHP applications

issue.body:
similar to #4052, the `callable` type doesn't guarantee that the function will be pure. in this case, I think it would be better to add a `pure-callable` type so that pure functions can still take a callable as an argument, and psalm can verify that it is pure.

pure-callable is just a normal callable but declared using the `@psalm-pure` annotation.

see: https://psalm.dev/r/50f8a9d0c2

impure behavior: https://3v4l.org/jQ4IT

issue.title: `count()` is considered `pure` by psalm, but its not.

repository.name: psalm
repository.description: A PHP static analysis tool for finding errors and security vulnerabilities in PHP applications

issue.body: `count` is not pure as it accepts all types of iterables ( see #4052 )

issue.title: Iterating over an object or an iterator in a pure context should be forbidden.

repository.name: psalm
repository.description: A PHP static analysis tool for finding errors and security vulnerabilities in PHP applications

issue.body:
following #4052 

the following should be forbidden: https://psalm.dev/r/7801a5f373 
> `$i` in this case is either an `Iterator` or `IteratorAggregate`, both are possibly-mutating.

the following should be forbidden: https://psalm.dev/r/ef206ffd4a
> `$i` in this case is an `Iterator` which is possibly-mutating.

issue.title: Is allowing iteration of `\Iterator` or `iterable` okay in `@psalm-mutation-free` context?

repository.name: psalm
repository.description: A PHP static analysis tool for finding errors and security vulnerabilities in PHP applications

issue.body:
Similar to https://github.com/vimeo/psalm/issues/4052

https://psalm.dev/r/9f3a5b7854

Given Iterator might be un-rewindable, therefore `yield from $this->i` could change its internal state, and subsequent yielding will give different results (probably, would yield nothing).
